title: Incorrect warning about unused declared dependencies causes build failure
body:
In some situations Qulice incorrectly reports "Unused declared dependencies found" which causes build failure. In reality, the dependency is used in code. Maven dependency plugin 2.10 reports "No dependency problems found" on the same project. This could maybe be due to Qulice using version 1.5 of Apache Maven Dependency Analyzer while version 1.6 exists (http://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.apache.maven.shared/maven-dependency-analyzer)

Steps to reproduce:
1. git clone https://github.com/RokiShopen/RandomDataGenerator.git
2. cd RandomDataGenerator/
3. git checkout experiment-datafiles
4. mvn -e clean dependency:analyze -PRandomDataGenerator

After step 4 Qulice will report **[WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found:
    org.thejavaguy:rng:jar:0.0.2:compile** and fail the build. More detailed log is attached here [bug_qulice_dependency_log.txt](https://github.com/teamed/qulice/files/317974/bug_qulice_dependency_log.txt)

When you try `mvn -e clean dependency:analyze -PNoQulice` you'll see that all dependencies are OK: [INFO] No dependency problems found

Environment used: Ubuntu 14.04LTS, Maven 3.3.9, Java 1.8.0_91

title: Prevent having a normal parameter following directly a parameter with a parenthesis
Checkstyle and PMD rules overlap
body:
Following checkstyle rules are equivalent of our PMD rules:

| Checkstyle | PMD |
| --- | --- |
| JavaNCSS (method and class) | NcssMethodCount, NcssConstructorCount, NcssTypeCount |
| CyclomaticComplexity | CyclomaticComplexity, StdCyclomaticComplexity, ModifiedCyclomaticComplexity |
| NPathComplexity | NPathComplexity |
| MethodLength | ExcessiveMethodLength |
| IllegalCatch | AvoidCatchingGenericException |
| UnusedImports | UnusedImports |
| FinalLocalVariableCheck | LocalVariableCouldBeFinal |

Please remove the checkstyle ones and make sure that PMD ones have at least the same threshold as the removed checkstyle checks (that is, we don't reduce code quality).

title: Qulice tolerates double whitespace in field decalaration
body:
I expect qulice to raise an issue for such a field declaration:

``` java
private  final  String  name;
```

This field declaration contains double whitespace between:
- `private` and `final`
- `final` and `String`
- `String` and `name`

A single white space character should be tolerated but not two.

title: Qulice release 0.16.4 is too slow
body:
Using qulice for some time, I realized that 0.16.4 release is much slower than the older ones. I tried to integrate qulice checking in a [simple (rather small) project](https://github.com/hdouss/jeometry) with 3 sub modules. The table below compares the maven build time when:
- running the build without qulice check
- running the build with qulice 0.16.3
- running the build with qulice 0.16.4

| Module | without qulice | with qulice 0.16.3 | with qulice 0.16.4 | Est. time taken by qulice 0.16.3 | Est. time taken by qulice 0.16.4 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Module 1 | 7.5s | 21s | 1min24s | 13.5s | 1min16s |
| Module 2 | 4s | 11s | 1min04s | 7s | 60s |
| Module 3 | 3s | 10s | 34s | 7s | 31s |

Every figure in this table is a mean build time of 3 builds. Even if these figures are not necessarily significant, it is obvious that 0.16.4 version has a performance issue (as I said before this was noticed in many other projects). I expect to figure out which new feature or which bug resolution has introduced this performance issue and to resolve it.

title: XML validator can't handle comments
body:
If there is a comment in XML file and N empty lines after the comment (where N >= 0), XML validator always complains that there should be N+1 empty lines. This effectively prohibits comments in XML files and I don't see reason why. In attached zip archive there are 2 XML files: valid.xml which passes validator and invalid.xml which doesn't. The only difference between them is a comment.

Other details that may be important: Windows 10 64-bit, Maven 3.3.9, qulice-maven-plugin 0.16.4, Java 1.8.0_77 64-bit.

[xmlbug.zip](https://github.com/teamed/qulice/files/232594/xmlbug.zip)

title: How to fix the violation SE_TRANSIENT_FIELD_NOT_RESTORED of FindBugs?
body:
Hi Qulice team,

I need some help to find the best way to fix the violation [_SE_TRANSIENT_FIELD_NOT_RESTORED: Transient field that isn't set by deserialization_](http://findbugs.sourceforge.net/bugDescriptions.html#SE_TRANSIENT_FIELD_NOT_RESTORED) of FindBugs in the project takes within the context of this ticket https://github.com/yegor256/takes/issues/660, my PR is https://github.com/yegor256/takes/pull/662. 

Indeed in the project _takes_ we have twice this kind of violation:
- In the class _HttpException_ [here](https://github.com/yegor256/takes/blob/65f4712ea2e21c02ce4655ce700778b2600d25fd/src/main/java/org/takes/HttpException.java#L46)
- In the class _RsForward_ [here](https://github.com/yegor256/takes/blob/65f4712ea2e21c02ce4655ce700778b2600d25fd/src/main/java/org/takes/facets/forward/RsForward.java#L65)

To "fix" those violations so far I proposed to proceed as next:
- For the class _HttpException_, I fixed the issue by removing the modifier _transient_ but I get a warning from PMD (_BeanMembersShouldSerialize_ ) complaining about the fact that I don't have any accessor which is not true here since I have the method _code()_ instead of the expected method _getStatus()_ so I suppressed the warning "PMD.BeanMembersShouldSerialize".
- For the class _RsForward_, I didn't find any obvious way to fix it since the variable _origin_ is not necessary _Serializable_ so it needs to remain _transient_ so I added the corresponding annotation SuppressFBWarnings.

So my question is: Do you have any better way to fix those violations to propose?

Thank you in advance,
BR,
Nicolas

title: Prohibit usage of '@author' Javadoc tag
body:
I don't see any reason why Qulice demands `@author` for every class. It usually is just a noise, because this information is in Git blame anyway. Moreover it gets outdated quickly, as after a few changes original author may have very little in common with a class.

Very rarely user of an API needs to know an author of particular item. Even if they want to know, the first point of contact is a GitHub/ticket anyway.

Apache already prohibits these tags: http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1037207/apache-enforces-the-removal-of-author-tags

Another article: https://www.databasesandlife.com/dont-use-the-author-javadoc-tag/

title: PMD's AvoidDuplicateLiterals is not equivalent to original MultipleStringLiteralsCheck
body:
In Qulice 0.16.4 `AvoidDuplicateLiterals` took over `MultipleStringLiteralsCheck`. However, these checks are not fully equivalent.

`MultipleStringLiteralsCheck` was by default ignoring duplicates in annotations, see http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/config_coding.html#MultipleStringLiterals. `AvoidDuplicateLiterals` doesn't do that, but it should, as it doesn't make sense to extract strings used in annotations to constants, especially if they are e.g. PMD exclusions.

Let's tune `AvoidDuplicateLiterals` to allow duplicates in annotations.

title: PMD and Checkstyle exclusions in pom.xml make a the build pass, but still cause checks to run and produces incorrect output.
body:
Observed this today when introducing Qulice into a legacy project.

Environment:
- Medium size legacy project
- ~4.3k PMD violations in ~300 files ( yes really :) )
  - => PMD takes a lot of time to run (2-3 min), right now only excluding it fully on all files makes sense for irrelevant reasons

Issue Observed:
- When putting `<exclude>pmd:.*</exclude>` the build passes which is correct, but:
  - The output is `[INFO] No PMD violations found in 3xx files`, this is not correct
  - It appears PMD is still run on those files given that the build is not sped up and the PMD step still takes  2-3 minutes

What I would like to see here :):
- The output should be more like `[INFO] No PMD violations found in 0 files`, or obviously even better no PMD output at all.
- PMD should not be run if all files are excluded to speed up the build in cases like the above described.
- Please also make sure that the same behaviour is implemented for Checkstyle, it too should only run on files not excluded!

title: Disable some rules for legacy project
body: I have a legacy project and want to provide qulice to it. But of course there are tons of violations - there is no resource to fix it at the time. So, I decided to fix first critical rules and with continuously refactoring improve code quality to perfect. Add @checkstyle excludes requires also a lot of time. SO is there a way to set up some set of rules at maven plugin? How do you manage legacy projects?

title: Static inner classes should be qualified with outer class always
String.split should be used only for simple cases
Prohibit declaring throws javadoc tag if there is no throws in signature
#61 start of logging unification
body:
#61
- migrated CheckstyleValidator to new logging (returning violations instead of throwing exception)
- fixed tests
- added todos to migrate rest of the file based validators

title: Prevent returning or declaring variables of concrete collection types
body:
Right now Qulice allows code like

``` java
final ConcurrentHashMap<String, String> map = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();
```

or

``` java
public ConcurrentHashMap<String, String> map() {
    ...
}
```

`ConcurrentHashMap` has interface `ConcurrentMap` and this one should always be preferred where possible.

Same rule should go to all other collections that have proper interfaces, i.e. all JDK concrete classes implementing `Collection` or `Map`.

Let's implement such check or reuse some existing one.

title: Prohibit dot in '@return' and '@param' tags for one sencence descritpions
Check formatting of POM file
body: Currently Qulice demands proper formatting for XML files. However, this check is not active for incorrectly formatted `pom.xml` in root directory. Let's make sure that this file is validated too.

title: Do not require capital letters for '@return' and '@param' tags
body:
Right now Qulice always demands capital letter after `@return` and `@param`. I propose to disable these checks, as they are contradicting with what Oracle suggests at http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/documentation/index-137868.html#@param that there are different styles.

The rule is especially not applicable to return tags, e.g. Qulice now requires strange

```
@return True when empty, false otherwise
```

instead of just

```
@return true when empty, false otherwise
```

There are also other resources that do not demand capital letters:
- http://blog.joda.org/2012/11/javadoc-coding-standards.html
- https://dev.liferay.com/participate/javadoc-guidelines

title: Exclude MultipleStringLiterals for tests
body:
This [article](http://www.yegor256.com/2014/04/27/typical-mistakes-in-java-code.html#redundant-constants)  says:

> Another typical mistake is to use constants in unit tests to avoid duplicate string/numeric literals in test methods. Don't do this! Every test method should work with its own set of input values.

Now we have rule MultipleStringLiterals that requires to introduce string to constant. This forces developer to extract constant that breaks concept of test independence. 
Moreover, let's make another rule to check test independence. It should violate if test method has reference to test class constant (probably aby other constant, but I'm not sure about this point)

title: Non-source code files should not be analyzed
body:
Qulice attempts to analyze all files in repository with some rules. This approach leads to requiring e.g. no trailing spaces at the end of line of image file:

```
[ERROR] /src/main/resources/favicon.ico[1]: Line has trailing spaces. (RegexpSinglelineCheck)
```

Please use `fileExtensions` from `FileTabCharacter` in all Regexp Checkstyle rules that we have in checks.xml.

title: Comma should not be allowed at the beginning of a line
body:
Right now Qulice does not complain on the following:

``` java
                    String.format(
                         "My name is %s"
                         , name
                     )
```

Let's disallow such comma placement. Google Java Style Guide says:

> A comma (,) stays attached to the token that precedes it

title: #701 Duplicated PMD and Checkstyle checks for multiple string literals
body: Duplicated PMD and Checkstyle checks for multiple string literals #701

title: Arrays.asList with a single argument should be Collections.singletonList
Qulice should use source level 1.7
body:
Qulice requires JDK 1.7 to run (FindBugs and PMD requirement), but we are still using source code level 1.6 inherited from jcabi-parent.
Let's compile the whole project using java 1.7 and:
1. use diamond operator in all places where new collection classes are created (make sure to remove potential LineLength suppressions or join lines that were wrapped because of the generic parameters)
2. Replace are cases where `AutoCloseable` is used with proper try-with-resources (in `DataSourceReader`, `FindBugsValidator`, `PMDValidatorTest`, `Prettifier`)
3. Use multi catch in `DependenciesValidator` and `Wrap`

title: Allow public nonstatic methods without references to this object
#659 prohibit public static methods
body:
For issue #659 
Added new rule to prohibit public static methods. 
~~Added puzzle to exclude rule StaticAccessToStaticFields.~~ Removed as not relevant.

title: #699 DefaultMavenEnvironmentTest.java:136-143: Ideally integration test is required
body: DefaultMavenEnvironmentTest.java:136-143: Ideally integration test is required... #699

title: Enforce spaces around colon in an enhanced for statement
body:
Right now Qulice accepts the following code:

``` java
for (final int number:numbers) {
    ...
}
```

I need to manually point it out during code reviews.

Let's enforce spaces around colon in foreach statements:

``` java
for (final int number : numbers) {
    ...
}
```

This is also recommendation in [Google Style Guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s4.6.2-horizontal-whitespace).

title: StaticAccessToStaticFields should be disabled for static initializers
Detect unnecessary semicolons at the end of class, method or constructor definitons
Enforce enum values naming convention
body:
Right now Qulice allows any name for enum constant:

``` java
enum MyEnum {
   anyName
}
```

As these are constants, we should allow the same pattern as for `static final` fields.

title: Constants should be on the right side of comparison
body: When comparing variables with constants there are two possible approaches: if (null == variable) or if (variable == null) Let's enforce the second one, so that constant value (string literal, `null` or number) is on the right side of comparison.

title: Enforce usage of diamond operator
body:
Qulice runs on Java 7 only, so let's add a check to enforce diamond operator usage wherever possible.

<hr id='w'>
- `715-04710633`/#752 (by )
- `715-2a207c32`/#776 (by )

title: Detect multiple unnecessary spaces
body:
Right now multiple obsolete spaces can only be spotted manually during code review: https://github.com/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=mentions%3Amkordas+%22double+space%22&type=Issues&ref=searchresults

Let's automate that check. Approach from Sevntu Checkstyle's `SingleSpaceSeparator` can be reused: https://github.com/sevntu-checkstyle/sevntu.checkstyle/blob/master/sevntu-checks/src/main/java/com/github/sevntu/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/SingleSpaceSeparatorCheck.java

title: Allow to use hardcoded IP in unit tests
body:
There are some projects which heavy use random IP addresses in unit tests.
These projects use the suppression `PMD.AvoidUsingHardCodedIP`.
Let's allow to use hardcoded IP in unit tests

title: Instance fields should be prohibited in Tests
XML validator should be fixed
body:
Right now XML validator is quite buggy and enforces strange indentation rules.
Let's fix it so following rules are checked in xml files:
- indentation should be 4 spaces, always (even when attributes are moved to the next line)

correct:

```
<test first="123"
    second="456>
</test>
```

incorrect:

```
<test first="123"
      second="456>
</test>
```
- force preambule with encoding tag (`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>`)
- prohibit two tags in the same line
  correct:

```
<first>
    <second>text</second>
</first>
```

incorrect:

```
<first><second>text</second></first>
```
- allow attributes to be wrapped (as I don't have idea how to add excludes inside xmls, so strict rules for line length would be too restrictive)

correct:

```
<test name="John">
</test>
```

```
<test
    name="John">
</test>
```

title: Prohibit empty lines before closing braces
Upgrade qulice to 0.16.2
body:
Let's upgrade our own qulice from 0.15.4 to 0.16.2 and:
- remove all unnecessary `transient` keywords.
- remove all LineLength excludes before lines with URLs (e.g. in qulice-checkstyle/src/main/java/com/qulice/checkstyle/JavadocTagsCheck.java)

title: Require newline between Javadoc contents and at-clauses
body:
Both [Google Style Guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s7.1.2-javadoc-paragraphs) and [Stephen Colebourne](http://blog.joda.org/2012/11/javadoc-coding-standards.html) recommend to put newline before the group of "at-clauses" if they are present.

In our code we have various approaches, I see some people adding them why others are removing.

According to https://github.com/teamed/qulice/issues/708#issuecomment-184518026, we should implement rule to require newline based on a Javadoc length.

This should be invalid:

``` java
  /**
   * Javadoc text.
   * 
   * @return the baz content, null if not processed
   */
  public String process() {...}
```

``` java
  /**
   * Javadoc text.
   *
   * Javadoc text.
   * @return the baz content, null if not processed
   */
  public String process() {...}
```

While this is correct:

``` java
  /**
   * Javadoc text.
   * @return the baz content, null if not processed
   */
  public String process() {...}
```

``` java
  /**
   * Javadoc text.
   *
   * Javadoc text.
   *
   * @return the baz content, null if not processed
   */
  public String process() {...}
```

title: Prohibit add comment to the first line of the Javadoc
False positive in BED_BOGUS_EXCEPTION_DECLARATION with jcabi-aspects
Type parameter descriptions should start with uppercase letter
body:
Following description is wrong:

```
/**
 * Searchable.
 *
 * @author Ivan Inozemtsev (ivan.inozemtsev@gmail.com)
 * @version $Id$
 * @since 2.15.2
 * @param <T> type of the items
 */
```

The `@param` part should start with uppercase letter:

```
 * @param <T> Type of the items
```

Add such check for both class and method type parameters.

title: static analysis on individual java files
body:
Is it possible for this project to execute static analysis on individual java files in a project?
A Software Developer may be working on a very huge java project and has added ONLY four files:

```
SimpleInterface.java
SimpleInterfaceImplementation.java
SimpleInterfaceMocker.java
SimpleInterfaceTest.java
```

Is it possible to carry out static analysis (one file at a time) on ONLY these four individual java files that have been created?

Is there such a command: `mvn clean -Pqulice=SimpleInterfaceMocker` in this project to enable them to do such a thing? This would be a real time saver!

The command to run a full Maven Build: `mvn clean install -Pqulice` performs static analysis on ALL projects files and most of the time this is NOT necessary since most of these files have not been edited or touched.

This wastes a lot of time and someone would ONLY like to run a full Maven Build at the very end just before they make a commit.

Maven has the command: `mvn -Dtest=SimpleInterfaceTest test` that executes ONLY a single test.

title: FindBugs needs the project to be re-compiled to update the results
body:
If I run `mvn qulice:check`, for example, I will get the list of issues.

Supposing I have one FindBugs issue to fix.

I fix it, and run `mvn qulice:check` again. But the issue still there. It only goes away if I run `mvn clean install qulice:check`.

This workflow works well for PMD and Checkstyle

For findbugs, if latest modification time of `*.java` files is newer then the oldest modification time of `*.class` file, we should "[WARN] Sources need to be recompiled for FindBugs check to work correctly".

title: Findbugs exclusions doesn't work in the same pattern as others
body:
In `pom.xml`, excluding singular files from findbugs like we do for checkstyle, for example, doesn't seem to work:

``` xml
<exclude>findbugs:/src/main/java/com/package/Class.java</exclude>
```

While excluding the entire project does work:

``` xml
<exclude>findbugs:.*</exclude>
```

And excluding singular files in this notation also work:

``` xml
<exclude>findbugs:package.Class</exclude>
```

This is rather confusing.

We could warn/error user if the user uses slashes in the exclude and print an example exclude to show how they should look like.

title: Qulice does not know that a method is commented
body:
I was testing some commenting script I am developing (it will search for todo-s and create a github issues automatically) and I noticed that if I do a comment like 

```

    /*
     * TODO $Subscribe to the update method /$
     *  #This method handles requests sent from the server must look something
     *  like this
     *  +(java)SignalRContext.PROXY.subscribe(
     *        new Object() {
     *            public void update() {
     *             }
     *        }
     *   );+
     *   /#
     */
```

qulice gives me this error message 

```
[ERROR] \src\main\java\com\interadria\bms\signalr\SignalRContext.java[60]: Missing a Javadoc comment. (JavadocMethodCheck)
[ERROR] \src\main\java\com\interadria\bms\signalr\SignalRContext.java[68]: Comments in method body are prohibited (MethodBodyCommentsCheck)
[ERROR] \src\main\java\com\interadria\bms\signalr\SignalRContext.java[69]: Comments in method body are prohibited (MethodBodyCommentsCheck)
[ERROR] \src\main\java\com\interadria\bms\signalr\SignalRContext.java[70]: Comments in method body are prohibited (MethodBodyCommentsCheck)
[ERROR] \src\main\java\com\interadria\bms\signalr\SignalRContext.java[71]: Comments in method body are prohibited (MethodBodyCommentsCheck)
[ERROR] \src\main\java\com\interadria\bms\signalr\SignalRContext.java[72]: Comments in method body are prohibited (MethodBodyCommentsCheck)
```

It treats the commented method as an actual method. I think this should not happen.
The syntax used in the the comment (+(java).. etc) has to do with the script I am working on but I don't think that this should matter if this is a comment don't validate it.

title: Fields should be marked transient only if class is Serializable
body:
Currently we have a PMD rule `BeanMembersShouldSerialize` with rationale:

> If a class is a bean, or is referenced by a bean directly or indirectly it needs to be serializable. Member variables need to be marked as transient, static, or have accessor methods in the class. Marking variables as transient is the safest and easiest modification. Accessor methods should follow the Java naming conventions, i.e. for a variable named foo, getFoo() and setFoo() accessor methods should be provided.

Most of the time we don't follow the rules for _Java Beans_ (see getters/setters) so I think that the rule requiring fields to be `transient` should be loose up to only `Serializable` classes - and there is already such rule enabled in Findbugs (SE_BAD_FIELD):

> This Serializable class defines a non-primitive instance field which is neither transient, Serializable, or java.lang.Object, and does not appear to implement the Externalizable interface or the readObject() and writeObject() methods.  Objects of this class will not be deserialized correctly if a non-Serializable object is stored in this field.

We should remove rule `BeanMembersShouldSerialize` and create a test that ensures we can create classes without transient fields.

title: squid:S2065 - Fields in non-serializable classes should not be "transient"
body:
This pull request is focused on resolving occurrences of Sonar rule squid:S2065 - Fields in non-serializable classes should not be "transient".
You can find more information about the issue here:
https://dev.eclipse.org/sonar/coding_rules#q=squid%3AS2065
Please let me know if you have any questions.
George Kankava

title: LineLength check should ignore content of @see javadoc annotation
body: LineLength check should ignore content of @see javadoc annotation Otherwise, it's impossible to have long links in it. For example ``` java /** * Min port number of range, according to IANA recommendations. * @checkstyle LineLength (1 line) * @see IANA recommendations */ private static final int RANGE_MIN = 49152; ``` checkstyle complains about AtclauseOrderCheck (@checkstyle before @see) But this code ``` java /** * Min port number of range, according to IANA recommendations. * @see IANA recommendations */ also didn't pass the check because of line length ```

title: Ignore lines between anon inner classes
body:
Issue: #653

2 caveats with this code I want to address
1. This implementation will have a slight, slight bug with double nested anonymous inner types. I just don't feel that writing all the code to make this check recursively check nested anonymous inner types is worth it, and it would make the code maintenance more of a burden to support a use-case that shouldn't exist (supporting double nested anonymous inner classes, really? :trollface: ).
2. ~~`EmptyLineCheck` is now no longer thread safe as it has to hold state of the lines which contain anonymous inner classes and method bodies. This is just a result of the fact that the API into checkstyle's is exposed as a streaming parsing API, as opposed to a fully loaded DOM. If it were DOM based, I could just setup the immutable objects ahead of time and let it all be sorted in a cleaner way. But it's not, so this is a caveat. The checkstyle API should certainly **not** be reusing plugin instances of the `Check` class, it should be created a `new` object per each file it validates with the `EmptyLineCheck` plugin. Provided that they are _not_ reusing instances, no problems will exist concerning parallel access. As every `EmptyLinesCheck` will be unique and there is no shared access concern at all.~~ It is thread safe now due to the usage of thread locals.

Lastly, regarding caveat 2, I built the project in parallel if that helps, it passed:
`mvn clean install -Pqulice -T 4`

title: Fix StringLiteralsConcatenationCheck
body:
Fix for #502. 
Add recursive string literal search.

title: Detect improper formatting of fluent calls
body:
According to [this article](http://www.yegor256.com/2014/10/23/paired-brackets-notation.html#fluent), fluent calls should be formatted like

``` java
new Bar()
    .with(
        veryLongListOfArguments
    )
    .with(argument)
```

instead of

``` java
new Bar()
    .with(
        veryLongListOfArguments
    ).with(argument)
```

I think we can very easily detect the latter. We just need to create check prohibiting pattern `^\s+\).\w+\(` in all Java files. I've run this regex search over a few project and I haven't seen any false-positives.

title: BracketsStructure check does not work for annotations
body:
Currently Qulice allows the following annotation above methods:

``` java
@RetryOnFailure(attempts = Tv.THREE, delay = Tv.HUNDRED,
    unit = TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
```

According to [this article](http://www.yegor256.com/2014/10/23/paired-brackets-notation.html) the above code should be prohibited in favour of:

``` java
@RetryOnFailure(
    attempts = Tv.THREE, delay = Tv.HUNDRED, unit = TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS
)
```

I'd expect extending `BracketsStructureCheck` with this functionality.

title: '@Test(expected = ...)' should not be allowed
body:
In Teamed projects I see [many usages](https://github.com/search?l=&q=%22%40Test%28expected+%3D+%22+user%3Ayegor256+user%3Ateamed&ref=advsearch&type=Code&utf8=%E2%9C%93) of `@Test(expected = ...)'` assertions.

`@Test(expected = ...)` is OK only for a tests containing only one method call, when exception is very specific and when there's absolutely no point in checking exception message. In all other cases such assertion may be very imprecise, and test may pass even when e.g. NPE was thrown during test initialization.

I think that proper usage of `@Test(expected = ...)` is so limited and misuse so common, that we should prohibit that code construct.

title: Qulice does not complain when project POM contains tab characters
body:
Currently Qulice prohibits any tab characters in the code and that works fine. However, it does not complain at all if `pom.xml` contains them.

For example in [takes](https://github.com/yegor256/takes/blob/master/pom.xml#L238) project POM is full of tabs and no one has noticed it.

title: NonStaticMethodCheck should ignore IT tests and small fixes
body:
1. Currently `NonStaticMethodCheck` ignores only classes that end in `Test`, but it should also ignore classes that end in `IT` and `ITCase`.
2. Also remove exclude of `NonStaticMethodCheck` in `qulice-spi/src/main/java/com/qulice/spi/Environment.java` file
3. Remove `else exit 0;` clause in years.sh file

title: Exlude old style junit assertions #646
body:
For issue #646 

Added custom PMD rule, check old style assertions in static imports or Assert.assert_; assert_ in test methods. 
Want to mention one thing:
If developer will use static import for `org.hamcrest.Matchers` and then will use `assertThat` - will get rule violation (rule restrict usage of all methods inside test method that starts with assert\* even private one)
Together with rule use name of static classes case above won't happen.

title: Javadoc of a test method should start with the class name
body:
Javadoc of each test method should start with the name of the class that is being tested (name of the test class with `Test` word removed).

e.g. for `Foo` class, following Javadoc is correct:

```
/**
 * Foo can do it.
 */
```

this one also is correct (uses inner class `Foo.Bar` inside a `FooTest`):

```
/**
 * Foo.Bar can do it.
 */
```

but this one is incorrect:

```
/**
 * Can do it, because it is a Foo.
 */
```

title: Check that test method name does not begin with 'test' or 'should'
body:
According to [this article](http://www.yegor256.com/2014/04/27/typical-mistakes-in-java-code.html#test-method-names) test method names should begin with a verb.

It's hard to enforce such convention, but at least we should create a check to prohibit names starting with the most popular `test` and `should` in methods annotated with `@Test`.

One exception would be method names starting with `tests`, as class responsibility may be to test something.

title: Check that second word in Javadoc for test is 'can'
body:
According to [this article](http://www.yegor256.com/2014/04/27/typical-mistakes-in-java-code.html#test-method-names) second word in Javadoc in every method annotated with `@Test` should be `can`.

Let's enforce that convention by creating check dedicated for that.

title: Ignore lines between anon inner classes #653
body:
For issue #653 

It is simply ignoring scanning down anonymous inner class structures. This does NOT ignore methods inside of anonymous inner classes, as the call to `visitToken` will trigger for EACH method inside of the anonymous inner type. Therefore empty lines inside of any method will still trigger an error. All unit tests work, including the previous unit tests inside `CheckTests.java`.

title: Check to make sure that abbreviations are written in camel case
body:
There's always debate whether acronyms in class names should be written in uppercase or in camelcase. However, both [Google](http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/reports/google-java-style.html#s5.3-camel-case) and [Microsoft](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/141e06ef%28v=vs.71%29.aspx) recommend making them camelcase meaning that we should prefer `XmlHttpRequest` over `XMLHTTPRequest`, which makes sesne also from readability perspective.

Let's enable and configure properly `AbbreviationAsWordInNameCheck` to prohibit class names like `XMLHTTPRequest`.

title: Prohibit 'public static' methods
body:
Methods that are `public static` are usually a sign of a [bad design](http://www.yegor256.com/2014/05/05/oop-alternative-to-utility-classes.html). Qulice should prohibit them with couple of exceptions:
- `public static void main(final String... args)`
-  methods annotated with `@Parameterized.Parameters`, `@BeforeClass`, `@AfterClass` and other JUnit annotations that must be used only with `public static` methods.

Classes or fields that are `public static` should not be prohibited by this check.

title: #623 Methods that throw exceptions are valid non-static methods
body: #623 Methods that throw exceptions are valid non-static methods. Updated the check and verified it with a change to the test.

title: UnnecessaryLocalRule has no test coverage
body:

`UnnecessaryLocalRule` has only one mention in the project - in file `src/main/resources/com/qulice/pmd/ruleset.xml`
Remove all declaration about `UnnecessaryLocalRule` from `ruleset.xml` and run test. Build success - that means no test coverage. 
I suppose it should be covered with test to avoid problems in future and for better documentation

title: Prohibit empty line at the start and at the end of javadoc.
body:
Following cases two cases should make qulice complain:
- empty javadoc line at the beginning:

```
/**
 *
 * Some text
 */
```
- empty javadoc line at the end:

```
/**
 * Some text
 *
 */
```

title: All usages of apache commons CharEncoding.UTF_8 should be prohibited
body:
`CharEncoding.UTF_8` (and the rest, like `CharEncoding.US_ASCII`) were used before JDK 1.7, but qulice requires this JDK so there is no point in allowing `CharEncoding`, users should use `StandardCharsets` from the JDK for the charsets.

`CharEncoding` exists in three libraries from apache: commons-lang, commons-lang3 and commons-codec. All of those should be prohibited and the user should get the message that he/she should use `StandardCharsets` instead.

title: Qulice inherits exclusion from jcabi-parent and XML files are not checked
body:
By default in `qulice` profile all validations for XMLs are disabled: https://github.com/jcabi/jcabi-parent/blob/0.41/pom.xml#L234. Qulice inherits that configuration and as an outcome XML files in the project are not validated. E.g. file `src/site/site.xml` does not have encoding specified.

To reproduce use command `mvn com.qulice:qulice-maven-plugin:check -Pqulice` - it that case parent configuration is ignored.

I'd expect all violations in XML files to be fixed and parent configuration to be overridden when invoking `mvn clean install -Pqulice`.

title: Enforce Qulice 0.15.4 over entire code
body:
Currently Qulice's code is validated using Qulice `0.15.2`. Let's update it to the latest version (currently `0.15.4`).

This task would require some smart way of assigning `@since` tag. I'd recommend making list of [release dates](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13208734/get-the-time-and-date-of-git-tags) and then retrieving from repository [creation date](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2390199/finding-the-date-time-a-file-was-first-added-to-a-git-repository) of each file.

title: Verify if method declaration does not take more lines than necessary
Prohibit usage of plain JUnit assertions
body:
For consistency reasons Qulice should not allow JUnit assertions from the following families:
- `org.junit.Assert.assert*`
- `junit.framework.Assert.assert*`

I'd expect Checkstyle or PMD violation on every such assertion. However, `Assert.fail()` should remain allowed.

Rationale is in http://www.yegor256.com/2014/04/28/xml-xpath-hamcrest-matchers.html:

> Hamcrest is my favorite instrument in unit testing. It replaces the JUnit procedural assertions of `org.junit.Assert` with an object-oriented mechanism. 

Moreover, I've seen mixed assertions in some projects which introduces confusion which one to use.

title: Qulice fails with unintuitive message on Log4j2 configuration
body:
When Qulice tries to validate XML without schema attached, e.g. Log4j2 configuration:

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<Configuration>
    <Appenders>
        <Console name="CONSOLE" target="SYSTEM_OUT">
            <PatternLayout pattern="[%p] %t %c: %m%n"/>
        </Console>
    </Appenders>
    <Loggers>
        <Root level="WARN">
            <AppenderRef ref="CONSOLE"/>
        </Root>
    </Loggers>
</Configuration>
```

it fails with the following message:

```
[WARNING] 1 XML validation error(s):
  -1:-1: cvc-elt.1: Cannot find the declaration of element 'Configuration'.
```

Qulice should not fail during analysis of XML files without schema.

> Qulice is a static analysis quality control instrument for Java projects. It combines all the best static analysis instruments and pre-configure them. **You don't need to use and configure them individually any more**.

title: PMD and Checkstyle unit tests should be isolated
body:
We have isolated unit tests for Checkstyle: `ChecksTest.java`. These are real unit test because they test every rule separately.
Let's refactor all of our Checkstyle tests, and the PMD tests to have this same approach in unit tests.

title: Add more flexibility to isolated unit tests
body:
We have very interesting unit tests for checkstyle `ChecksTest`. These tests are isolated because every rule is tested in an isolated manner. The only problem with these tests is they lack some flexibility, because they expect in the associated resource: 
- 1 Invalid.java file
- 1 Valid.java file
- 1 violations.txt file

Let's make these tests more flexible by making them work with:
- 0 or many Invalid-xxx.java files
- 0 or many Valid-xxx.java files
- 0 or many (as many Invalid-xxx.java) violations-xxx.txt files, eaxh one of these should have a same suffix to one of the Invalid-xxx files.

title: Ignore LineLength check on lines containing links
body:
Right now Checkstyle's `LineLength` check complains on lines with > 80 chars containing lengthy links. The only thing that implementer can do is to use suppression, as links cannot be divided across the lines, e.g.:

```
  /**
   * First sentence.
   * @author Yegor Bugayenko (yegor@tpc2.com)
   * @version $Id$
   * @since 1.0
   * @checkstyle LineLengthCheck (1 line)
   * @link https://github.com/teamed/qulice/blob/0c2bff851aad6ac5a23f4e43dd8bace68a3013db/qulice-maven-plugin/src/main/java/com/qulice/maven/DefaultMavenEnvironment.java
   */
```

I'd expect all lines containing `http://` or `https://` to be skipped from this check.

title: findbugs filters are broken
body:
I tried to enable findbugs for Netbout - and found that exclude filters don't work. The only valid filter is regular expression that match empty string, for example `^$`. Here is actual example from netbout pom.xml:

```
                    <groupId>com.qulice</groupId>
                    <artifactId>qulice-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                    <configuration>
                        <excludes>
                            <!--
                            @todo #911 Fix findbugs errors once findbugs filters are fixed
                            -->
                            <exclude>findbugs:^$</exclude>
                        </excludes>
```

and it works wrong - excludes everything. I expect that empty string matches to none of classes.

Few more examples, there is a module netbout-spi, all classes are in package com.netbout.spi. Without any exclude section it provides errors:

> [WARNING] FindBugs: L D NP: friend must be non-null but is marked as nullable  At Friends.java:[lines 122-124]
> [WARNING] FindBugs: L D NP: friend must be non-null but is marked as nullable  At Friends.java:[lines 143-145]
> [WARNING] FindBugs: L D NP: input must be non-null but is marked as nullable  At Attachments.java:[lines 166-168]
> [WARNING] FindBugs: L P SIC: The class com.netbout.spi.Friends$Search$1 could be   refactored into a named _static_ inner class  At Friends.java:[lines 118-124]
> [WARNING] FindBugs: L P SIC: The class com.netbout.spi.Friends$Search$2 could be refactored into a named _static_ inner class  At Friends.java:[lines 139-145]
> [WARNING] FindBugs: L P SIC: The class com.netbout.spi.Attachments$Search$1 could be refactored into a named _static_ inner class  At Attachments.java:[lines 162-168]

However, following excludes do not work:
    `<exclude>findbugs:Friends</exclude>`
    `<exclude>findbugs:com.netbout.spi.Friends</exclude>`
    `<exclude>findbugs:com.netbout.spi.*</exclude>`
    `<exclude>findbugs:/src/main/java/com/netbout/spi/Friends.java</exclude>`

title: Implement check to prohibit Javadoc in methods with '@Override'
body:
As agreed in #555 Javadocs in methods annotated with '@Override' should be prohibited. It's because users may have a different understanding of your method based on whether they examine the method in the supertype or the subtype and it may cause confusion.

There's implicit automatic Javadoc inheritance so also putting just `{@inheritDoc}` would be obsolete.

The check could be named e.g. `NoJavadocForOverrideMethods`.

Please do not forget to add various tests for different possible locations of Javadoc.

title: Allow 'id' as a variable name
body:
Currently Qulice prohibits variable named just 'id', e.g.

``` java
final int id = readAttribute("id");
```

I don't see anything bad in using `id` as variable name, it is very common and widely accepted.

To overcome it, people use a lot of creativity. I've seen variables named like:
- `ide`
- `ident`
- `identifier`
- `attrid`
- `attribute`
- `name`
- `xid`

and so on, instead of simple `id`.

I'd expect `id` to be allowed as final/non-final local variable names, method parameters, fields and constants (`ID`). It should be prohibited for catch parameters.

```
/**

 * @version $Id$
 * @todo #123:30min Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test Test
 */
```

LineLength check doesn't fail, but it should, we ignore line length on every line where there is a javadoc tag.

Please fix it to check also javadoc tag lines.

title: Guava 'Lists.newArrayList' is not checked to have initial capacity
body:
We have the following custom check that requires `new ArrayList()` declarations to have initial capacity:

``` xml
    <module name="com.qulice.checkstyle.ConditionalRegexpMultilineCheck">
        <property name="condition" value="^import java\.util\.ArrayList;$"/>
        <property name="format" value="new ArrayList(?:<.*?>)?\(\)"/>
        <property name="message"
                  value="ArrayList should be initialized with a size parameter"/>
        <property name="fileExtensions" value="java"/>
    </module>
```

There is no verification for Guava's `Lists.newArrayList()` though. These declarations should be required to have initial capacity too by another custom check configuration.

Moreover, all the occurrences of such violations in Qulice should be fixed in scope of this issue: https://github.com/teamed/qulice/search?q=newarraylist

There should be test added to check whether copyright is 2011-current year. It should check at least `.java`, `.xml`, `.vm`, `.groovy`, `.txt`, `.fml`, `.properties` extensions.

title: Checkstyle and PMD report errors with incorrect path
body:
Both Checkstyle and PMD are reporting errors with leading slash, which is not correct.
More over if run on multimodule project they don't include the module directory in the path.

Example:

```
log4j:WARN See http://logging.apache.org/log4j/1.2/faq.html#noconfig for more info.
[ERROR] /src/test/java/com/qulice/checkstyle/CheckstyleValidatorTest.java[117]: Indentation (16) must be same or less than previous line (8), or bigger by exactly 4 (CascadeIndentationCheck)
[ERROR] /src/main/java/com/qulice/checkstyle/CheckstyleValidator.java[119]: Indentation (16) must be same or less than previous line (8), or bigger by exactly 4 (CascadeIndentationCheck)
[INFO] Read our quality policy: http://www.qulice.com/quality.html
```

In the above example there shouldn't be a leading slash and the above classpath should show the path relative to the current directory (so module names should be included in the path).

title: Let's eat our own dogfood
body:
Before merging each code we should run newly built qulice against qulice codebase.
This will allow us to catch errors in our checks earlier.

We should have another travis build (only travis) that will do the validations using newly built plugin - it is because sometimes we introduce incompatible changes that could fail on our current codebase, but we can't updated it because it will fail on the previous qulice plugin.
So we should have a build that will be just an information for us, what new violations are being detected. This should allow us to fix invalid ones.

Options how to do it:
1.
- `mvn clean install`
- `mvn com.qulice:qulice-maven-plugin:1.0-SNAPSHOT:check -Pqulice` (here we will probably need to add excludes e.g. `-Dqulice.excludes="xml:.*,checkstyle:.*,pmd:.*/src/test/resources/.*"`)

2.
- add option to define qulice version from command line (by using `<properties>` tag)
- `mvn clean install`
- `mvn versions:set "-DnewVersion=1.1"`
- `mvn clean install -Pqulice -Dqulice.version=1.0-SNAPSHOT`
1. Any other ideas

For the 1 and 2, we should also make sure that we run the build for all the modules, so some shell magic will be needed to enter each directory and build given plugin.

title: No check to ensure empty lines are present where needed
Check to prohibit just '{@inheritDoc}'
Only ArrayList is checked to have initial capacity
body:
We have the following custom check:

``` xml
    <module name="com.qulice.checkstyle.ConditionalRegexpMultilineCheck">
        <property name="condition" value="^import java\.util\.ArrayList;$"/>
        <property name="format" value="new ArrayList(?:<.*?>)?\(\)"/>
        <property name="message"
                  value="ArrayList should be initialized with a size parameter"/>
        <property name="fileExtensions" value="java"/>
    </module>
```

It checks only `ArrayList` to have proper initial capacity. Checks for at least these classes are missing:
- `java.util.HashMap`
- `java.util.TreeMap`
- `java.util.HashSet`
- `java.util.LinkedHashSet`

title: Two 'package-info.java' files and too much line length suppressions
body:
Two things to be done in this issue:
1. My javac 1.8.0_66 compiler in IntelliJ is warning me every time that  `package-info.java file has already been seen for package com.qulice.findbugs`. Indeed, we have two of them:
   - `qulice-findbugs/src/mock/java/com/qulice/findbugs/package-info.java`
   - `qulice-findbugs/src/main/java/com/qulice/findbugs/package-info.java`
   
   Whenever I remove any of them to be javac compliant I get `Missing package-info.java file. (JavadocPackageCheck)` though.
   
   I'd expect moving `src/mock/com/qulice/findbugs/BytecodeMocker.java` to `src/java/com/qulice/findbugs/mock/BytecodeMocker.java` and removing entire `src/mock/` directory, as it looks obsolete.
2. Majority of `// @checkstyle LineLength (x lines)` should be removed from Qulice codebase. They distract code reader forcing to scroll horizontally and give bad example.
   
   Right now there are 21 of them: https://github.com/teamed/qulice/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=%22%40checkstyle+linelength+%28%22
   - some are completely obsolete (line is shorter or contains import - long imports should be allowed)
   - in most of the remaining cases suppressions were made to not have violations when concatenation strings - but the correct approach is described at http://www.yegor256.com/2014/06/19/avoid-string-concatenation.html

title: XmlValidator should properly fail XML files without schema
body:
Unit test for #498.

XmlValidator should properly fail XML files without schema with `ValidationException`. And it does inside `qulice-xml` module that uses `jcabi-xml` version **0.15**. `qulice-maven-plugin` on the other hand uses  `jcabi-xml` version **0.17** and fails the same test with vague `NullPoinerException`.

Easily reproducible by updating `jcabi-xml` version inside `qulice-xml/pom.xml` to **0.17**.

Probably caused by https://github.com/jcabi/jcabi-xml/issues/94.

title: UseConcurrentHashMap, AvoidUsingVolatile and DoNotUseThreads PMD rules should be disabled
body:
1. UseConcurrentHashMap PMD rule is triggering for every `HashMap` instantiation. `ConcurrentHashMap` has unnecessary memory overhead and it shouldn't be general replacement for `HashMap`. Please see https://ria101.wordpress.com/2011/12/12/concurrenthashmap-avoid-a-common-misuse/
   
   Especially when `HashMap` is created within a method and isn't returned from it, there's absolutely no point in making it concurrent.
   
   I'd expect this rule being disabled and all unnecessary usages of `ConcurrentHashMap` like e.g. in https://github.com/teamed/qulice/blob/f1842e14d8a5cb92efd48befd62dc3dc4ac9d00a/qulice-checkstyle/src/main/java/com/qulice/checkstyle/JavadocTagsCheck.java#L70 should be replaced with `HashMap` or equivalent.
2. Disable AvoidUsingVolatile rule, as it makes sense only for Java 1.4 projects, where `volatile` was generally broken and semantics changed in Java 5.
3. Disable DoNotUseThreads rule, as it makes sense only in J2EE environment (according to PMD docs: The J2EE specification explicitly forbids the use of threads.)

title: BracketStructureCheck doesn't work for try-with-resources
setMinimumPriority in SourceValidator is misleading and unnecessary
body:
All pmd tests are handled by the `SourceValidator` class and ultimately end up in `validateOne` method which has the following misleading statement:

```
factory.setMinimumPriority(RulePriority.valueOf(5));
```

I don't know what the reasons were for setting a minimum priority of `level 5` for all tests, but this is both misleading and confusing. For one, it isn't working at all. For example, there are tons of rules in the pmd [basic.xml](https://github.com/pmd/pmd/blob/master/pmd-java/src/main/resources/rulesets/java/basic.xml) and some custom rules in our own [ruleset.xml](https://github.com/teamed/qulice/blob/ebf85bd3162241d029b6796da98e91d2d08228cc/qulice-pmd/src/main/resources/com/qulice/pmd/ruleset.xml) that have a priority level of 3 which is below 5, but still they are working.

Secondly, if a validation isn't working, a developer may think that it is because of this set `priority level` which is very misleading.

I hence recommend to remove this priority check if it isn't defeating any other design goals that `qulice-pmd` may have.

Our coding standard require each top-level class to have `@since` tag.

Qulice should complain when this tag is missing. It could be implemented as e.g. custom Checkstyle check.

Sample code that should cause violation:

```
+/** 
+ * Some class.
+ *
+ * @author John Doe (sample@mail.com)
+ * @version $Id$ 
+ */
```

Correct Javadoc:

```
/**
 * Some class.
 *
 * @author John Doe (sample@mail.com)
 * @version $Id$
 * @since 1.0
+ */
```

title: Checkstyle Unit Tests are coupled
body:
Checkstyle and PMD unit tests rely on availability of strings inside the logger output. Unit tests run on different threads (whether they are forked or not). It can happen that one test (i.e one thread) logs an error message that will be tested by another one and a false positive happens.
**Example :**
Test 1 checks and expects for error message "Checkstyle Error"
1. Test 1 (thread one) : arrives at point of execution L296 : after writer 1 is appended
2. Test 2 (thread two) : arrives at point of execution L312 : Checkstyle performs its checks and prints an output message "Checkstyle Error" on appenders of RootLogger (including writer 1)
3. Test 1 : continues execution, CheckStyle check fails due to another error and does not report "Checkstyle Error"

The Test 1 should fail but won't fail

**How to reproduce ?**
Add this test to `CheckstyleValidatorTest` (same logic for `PMDValidatorTest`) : 

``` java
    /**
     * CheckstyleValidator can report error.
     * @throws Exception In case of error
     */
    @Test
    public void reportsError() throws Exception {
        this.validateCheckstyle(
            "ReturnCount.java", false,
            Matchers.containsString(
                "Type Javadoc comment is missing an @param <T> tag."
            )
        );
    }
```

This test should fail because `ReturnCount.java` does not have parameters and Checkstyle should not produce the message `Type Javadoc comment is missing an @param <T> tag.` when checking `ReturnCount.java`.
The build could succeed (about 50% of the time) because `reportsErrorWhenParameterObjectIsNotDocumented` is causing the message to be appended on the `reportsError` (added test) writer.


while full list should look like

```

ConstantUsage

EmptyLines
ImportCohesion

JavadocTags
MethodBodyComments
MethodsOrder
MultilineJavadocTags
NonStaticMethod
ProtectedMethodInFinalClass
StringLiteralsConcatenation
```

Moreover, all Qulice's custom PMD rules should be listed at http://www.qulice.com/quality.html#PMD

title: Upgrade to PMD 5.4.1
body:
Qulice currently uses PMD 5.3.4. Let's upgrade to the newest version and we'll get those things:
- https://pmd.github.io/pmd-5.3.5/overview/changelog.html
- https://pmd.github.io/pmd-5.4.0/overview/changelog.html
- https://pmd.github.io/pmd-5.4.1/overview/changelog.html

I'd suggest to make sure that the following new checks are enabled after update:
- Basic: SimplifiedTernary (rulesets/java/basic.xml/SimplifiedTernary)
  Ternary operator with a boolean literal can be simplified with a boolean expression.
- Clone: CloneMethodMustBePublic (rulesets/java/clone.xml/CloneMethodMustBePublic)
  The java manual says “By convention, classes that implement the Cloneable interface should override Object.clone (which is protected) with a public method.”
- Clone: CloneMethodReturnTypeMustMatchClassName (rulesets/java/clone.xml/CloneMethodReturnTypeMustMatchClassName)
  If a class implements Cloneable the return type of the method clone() must be the class name.
- Design: SingletonClassReturningNewInstance (rulesets/java/design.xml/SingletonClassReturningNewInstance)
  Verifies that the method called getInstance returns a cached instance and not always a fresh, new instance.
- Design: SingleMethodRule (rulesets/java/design.xml/SingleMethodSingletonRule)
  Verifies that there is only one method called getInstance. If there are more methods that return the singleton, then it can easily happen, that these are not the same instances - and thus no singleton.

We should make sure that the following rule is disabled, as we have different convention for `this` usage:
- Unnecessary: UselessQualifiedThis (rulesets/java/unnecessary.xml/UselessQualifiedThis)
  Flags unnecessary qualified usages of this, when this alone would be unique. E.g. use just this instead of Foo.this.

Pay attention to rename that happened:
- UseSingleton -> UseUtilityClass

title: maven-failsafe-plugin freezes on integration-test goal
body:
I was looking into Issue [#791](https://github.com/yegor256/netbout/issues/791) on the netbout project when I came across this. There is no issue with the normal build, but integration-test is actually just freezing.  Apart from [@hs3180](https://github.com/hs3180), I can replicate the issue too. Basically, the following plugin declaration is the culprit (`/netbout-client/pom.xml`):

```
    <plugin>
        <artifactId>maven-failsafe-plugin</artifactId>
        <configuration>
            <systemPropertyVariables>
                <netbout.token>${netbout.token}</netbout.token>
            </systemPropertyVariables>
        </configuration>
        <executions>
            <execution>
                <goals>
                    <goal>integration-test</goal>
                    <goal>verify</goal>
                </goals>
            </execution>
        </executions>
    </plugin>
```

The goal `integration-test` needs to be analyzed in depth as to why its causing the build to freeze.

I would excpect all of them being enforced by Qulice.

title: Cascade indentation check is required
body:
We removed `CascadeIndentationCheck` in https://github.com/teamed/qulice/issues/265 and it was a bad idea. We must check that each line indentation is either:
1. the same as previous one or less
2. bigger than previous by exactly 4

All other cases must cause a failure.

title: CheckstyleValidatorTest have much code redundancy
body:
Many methods in `CheckstyleValidatorTest` use the same code logic. This code logic is already encapsulated in `validateCheckstyle` method and is used by test methods : `acceptsDefaultMethodsWithFinalModifiers`, `acceptsSingleNameAuthor`, `acceptsConstantUsedInMethodAnnotation`, `acceptsConstructorParametersNamedJustLikeFields`.

Other test methods are not using `validateCheckstyle` method and the same code is repeated over and over. These methods are : `catchesCheckstyleViolationsInLicense`, `acceptsInstanceMethodReferences`, `reportsErrorWhenParameterObjectIsNotDocumented`, `passesWindowsEndsOfLineWithoutException`, `testWindowsEndsOfLineWithLinuxSources`.
This makes the test class unusefully long and unmaintainable.

title: No documentation for PomXpathValidator
body:
Any page on http://www.qulice.com/ does not mention anything about feature to make various checks on POM file:

```
<configuration>
    <asserts>
        <param>/pom:project/pom:build/pom:plugins/pom:plugin[pom:artifactId='qulice-maven-plugin']/pom:artifactId/text()</param>
        <param>/pom:project/pom:dependencies/pom:dependency[pom:artifactId='commons-io']/pom:version[.='1.2.5']/text()</param>
    </asserts>
</configuration>
```

Short description of possibility to make assertions on POM and sample usage should be presented on http://www.qulice.com/qulice-maven-plugin/usage.html

It should be also documented which namespace prefix is used. Currently it is `pom` for `http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0`.

title: Leftovers after removal of RedundantThrows check from Checkstyle
body:
RedundantThrows was removed from Checkstyle at version 6.2 (https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/473), because it was too buggy.

Due to problems with it, Qulice had many workarounds for it - mainly suppressions. When this check was removed from Qulice there was no proper cleanup.

All occurrences of `RedundantThrows` should be removed from code. Currently we have 22 of them, e.g.:
- https://github.com/teamed/qulice/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=RedundantThrows&type=Code
- https://github.com/teamed/qulice/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=RedundantThrowsCheck&type=Code

`RedundantThrowsCheckTest` should be removed too, as it become obsolete.

title: Documentation does not mention how to exclude files from XML analysis
body:
The page http://www.qulice.com/qulice-maven-plugin/example-exclude.html represented as https://github.com/teamed/qulice/blob/master/qulice-maven-plugin/src/site/apt/example-exclude.apt.vm in repository does not contain information how to exclude XML files from analysis.

Such exclusions are used many times in [Qulice itself](https://github.com/teamed/qulice/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=%22%3Cexclude%3Exml%3A%22), so looks like such documentation might be handy for users.

title: NewlineAtEndOfFile does not work for files other than Java
body:
Good practice is to end all source and text files with newline. A text file under Unix, consists of a series of lines, each of which ending with a newline character (`\n`). It is required by POSIX standard:
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/729692/why-should-text-files-end-with-a-newline

Currently Qulice checks [only Java files](https://github.com/teamed/qulice/blob/master/qulice-checkstyle/src/main/resources/com/qulice/checkstyle/checks.xml#L50) according to this rule:

``` xml
    <module name="NewlineAtEndOfFile">
        <property name="fileExtensions" value="java"/>
        <property name="lineSeparator" value="lf"/>
    </module>
```

This should be extended to handle all typical extensions that are known to be text-based files in typical Maven projects.

title: Non-Java specific checks in Checkstyle do not define file extensions properly
body:
There are two issues with current Checkstyle configuration in Qulice for non-Java specific checks.
#### FileTabCharacter

This check is currently configured [as follows](https://github.com/teamed/qulice/blob/311cd7251a2fc149b3dd53f67219b9fe4a3c2cf4/qulice-checkstyle/src/main/resources/com/qulice/checkstyle/checks.xml#L76)

``` xml
<property name="fileExtensions" value="java,txt,xml,xsl,xsd,properties,groovy,vm,MF,sh,sql,tokens,g,spec,css,csv"/>
```

It means, that Qulice allows tab characters in commonly used source files in our projects like:
- `js`, `scss`, `json` - for web development
- `md` - for documentation
- `yml` - for configuration
- `gradle` - for build scripts
- `dtd` - for schemas

This should be fixed.

To reproduce e.g. add to project with Qulice `helloWorld.js` with the following contents:

```
\tconsole.log("Hello World");
```

Where `\t` is tab character.
#### NewlineAtEndOfFile

Good practice is to end all source and text files with newline. A text file under Unix, consists of a series of lines, each of which ending with a newline character (\n). It is required by POSIX standard:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/729692/why-should-text-files-end-with-a-newline
Currently Qulice checks only Java files according to this rule:

```
<module name="NewlineAtEndOfFile">
    <property name="fileExtensions" value="java"/>
    <property name="lineSeparator" value="lf"/>
</module>
```

This should be extended to handle all typical extensions that are known to be text-based files in typical Maven projects.

To reproduce use any project with Qulice and just remove line at the end of any non-java file. Observe that Qulice doesn't complain.

title: Qulice does not enforce Checkstyle rule NoLineWrap
body:
[NoLineWrap](http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/config_whitespace.html#NoLineWrap) check is not enforced by qulice-checkstyle, I think someone just forgot to enable it. Wrapping package and import statements should be prohibited:
- https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s3.2-package-statement
- https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s3.3.2-import-line-wrapping

title: Build fails under non-english JVM
body:
When we try to build the project under a JVM that don't have english as the default locale, the unit tests fails. This is due to the checkstyle messages that are localized. `com.qulice.checkstyle.CheckstyleValidatorTest` is trying to look for messages like "hides a field" or "Type Javadoc comment is missing" inside Checkstyle output.
The issue is very common under a non-english Windows, where the JVM default locale would be the Windows installation language. The bug is reproducible in a language where localisation is supported in Checkstyle (like French, German, Spanish, Japanese...).
To reprouce the issue in **any** environment, it is enough to run the command : 
`mvn clean install -Pqulice -DargLine="-Duser.language=fr -Duser.country=FR"`

title: [question] Why com.qulice:qulice-gradle-plugin:0.14 produces qulice-plugin (gradle)?
body: Hi all! I have a simple question: why `com.qulice:qulice-gradle-plugin:0.14` produces `qulice-plugin` instead of `qulice` or `com.qulice.gradle` etc.? Thank you. refs #404

title: [question] Why the release number is not flowing semver?
body: Hi all! I have a simple question - why the release number is not flowing [semver](http://semver.org/)? Thank you.

title: #514 POM and README do not specify minimal Maven version as 3.1.0
body: #514 `prerequisites` maven tag is deprecated, and not inherited. The solution uses maven-enforcer-plugin.

title: Log4j warning in execution logs
body:
Qulice execution logs contain log4j warnings:

```
[INFO] --- qulice-maven-plugin:0.14:check (default) @ template-project ---
[INFO] Starting Checkstyle validator
[INFO] LICENSE found: file:config/header.txt
log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.ConfigurationLoader).
log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly.
log4j:WARN See http://logging.apache.org/log4j/1.2/faq.html#noconfig for more info.
```

Logs should not be polluted with such warnings.

To reproduce the issue you can use simplest possible Maven project with Qulice:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/maven-v4_0_0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>any</groupId>
    <artifactId>any</artifactId>
    <version>any</version>
    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>com.qulice</groupId>
                <artifactId>qulice-maven-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>0.14</version>
                <configuration>
                    <license>file:${basedir}/header</license>
                </configuration>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <phase>validate</phase>
                        <goals>
                            <goal>check</goal>
                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>
```

and run `mvn validate`.

title: allow custom checkstyle check.xml

Qulice master won't build for me, and neither will this branch, so I unfortunately can't verify that it works.

title: Custom rules
body:
AS A
Dev using Qulice.

I WANT
To customize the preconfigured rules.

SO THAT
Rules I want enforced but are not in Qulice are enforced, rules I don't want enforced are not enforced.

EG

```
<configuration>
  <checkstyle>file:${basedir}/checks.xml</checkstyle>
  <pmd>file:${basedir}/ruleset.xml</pmd>
<configuration>
```

OR

```
<configuration>
  <excludes>
    <exclude>checkstyle.JavadocMethod:/src/examples/.*</exclude>
    <exclude>findbugs.UC_USELESS_OBJECT:~com.qulice.foo.*</exclude>
  </excludes>
<configuration>
```

MISC
Apologies if this is already possible and I'm missing something. (I browsed through the docs but could find anything that suggests this is supported)

title: Running mvn clean install creates a lot of files in parent folder
body:
Each time I run `mvn clean install`, a `project:findbug_excludes_SOME_NUMER.xml` file is created at the parent folder.

The contents looks like:

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<FindBugsFilter>
   <Match>
      <Or>
         <Class name="/src/it/.*"/>
      </Or>
   </Match>
</FindBugsFilter>
```

Every once in a while I clean those files up, but it's kind of annoying:

```
$ ls project*
project:findbug_excludes_1446682337609964000.xml  project:findbug_excludes_38443475077025.xml
project:findbug_excludes_1447450097609404000.xml  project:findbug_excludes_52548913696264.xml
project:findbug_excludes_236938902230540.xml      project:findbug_excludes_78846565333859.xml

project:
LICENSE.txt  README.md  pom.xml  src/
```

I think it should not create those files, at  least, not in the parent folder.

title: HeaderCheck needs explanation
body:
I'm just not sure that I understand everything correctly. `HeaderCheck` needs this lines to be the first statement in the header javadoc:

```
 * Copyright (c) 2011-2014, Qulice.com
```

So, basically, my question is: Why should I put this copyright to _my_ code? I already included the license, that means that I respect Qulice and I do not pretend that it's my library. But, the code where it forces me to put this copyright, is the code that was created by me. I used Qulice in process of this code creation, that's true, license proofs that. But does it mean that this code was created by Qulice, JetBrains, Apple, company that produces the coffee I drink? I'm using all of them when I'm programming, should I put copyright of them all to the header? Who's gonna be the first in line? Of course, Qulice, because it just won't work without it. To me sounds a little bit strange. Could someone explain this to me, please? :)

title: AvoidInstantiatingObjectsInLoops prohibits instantiating the Iterable we're iterating over
body:
This code would not pass qulice check, but it should:

``` java
for (final Integer number : new ArrayList<Integer>(Tv.TEN)) {
    number.intValue();
}
```

PMD treats `new ArrayList<Integer>(Tv.TEN)` as an object instantiated inside a loop. 

One might argue if it is actually _inside_ the loop, but anyway I think that this violation should not happen in this case.

Of course, that is not a particularly good piece of code, it is just a minimal reproducible example.

Disallowing instantiating the `Iterable` in the loop head makes us use a one-time variable, which would be another quality issue.

A similar issue in PMD bug tracker: http://sourceforge.net/p/pmd/bugs/1215/

title: Generic parameters should be documented
body:
This code will pass qulice test

``` java
/**
 * Box with content.
 * @author Sam (sam@i.am)
 * @version $Id$
 * @since 0.5
 */
public interface Box<T> {

}
```

The problem here that parameter `T` is not documented. Qulice should disallow that. Instead, the correct code would be:

``` java
/**
 * Box with content.
 * @author Sam (sam@i.am)
 * @version $Id$
 * @since 0.5
 * @param <T> Type of content
 */
public interface Box<T> {

}
```

title: We should be able to have constructor parameters with the same names as the fields
body:
We have a rule that parameters' names must be different from fields' names. Generally it is really useful and helps prevent some overlooked problems. 

But there is one exception. This rule is absolutely _destructive_ to code quality when applied to constructors.

Generally we have just assignments in constructors:

``` java
public Rectangle(final int w, final int h) {
    this.width = w;
    this.height = h;
}
```

Parameters in constructors must be the same things as the fields, because they are just assigned to fields and not operated upon in any way. And if thing A and thing B are the same thing used for the same reason, then A and B should have the same name. But they can't because of our rules.

Current rule leads to us inventing synonyms, like `w` instead of `width` and `h` instead of `heght`. Sometimes those synonyms are easy to figure out, sometimes they are really hard. I don't think we should be doing this. Synonyms in code are a disaster.

Another thing is that a constructor parameter's name and field name are important for different reasons. Constructor parameter names show up in completion dialogues in IDE, and field names show up in the code of class. Both constructor parameters and fields should have expressive names, but our quality standards don't allow them both to be maximally expressive.
### What we should do

I think that we should be _enforcing_ constructor parameters to have the same names as field names. Current approach harms code quality, and the suggested approach actually improves it. A properly designed class would never actually need a constructor parameter to have different name from the field it is stored in.

If it is too difficult to enforce the naming for constructor parameters (or if you think that it is not a good idea), then at least excluding constructor parameters from the `HiddenFieldCheck` would be a huge improvement.

It basically asks to remove the `<?xml version="1.0"?>` header, glue together the end of the header license with the start of the `project` tag, change some indentation that makes no sense , and, finally, asks to remove the last empty line - which also doesn't make any sense.

But, even If I do all the changes, it keeps complaining about an un-existent empty line at the end of the file.

Seems a bug for me... is there any chance that some dependencies of the project are messing up with qulice?

body:
The method calling formatting for lines with more than 80c is:

``` java
this.work(
  lot,
  of,
  parameters,
  just,
  to,
  exemplify
)
```

I think that we should use this same pattern for method declaration:

``` java
public boolean flush(
  final int job,

  final Runnable callback
) throws IOException {
```

title: PMD doesn't recognize method references
body:
If I have a method that is used only as a method reference, then PMD will complain that it is not used anywhere.

Adding `net.sourceforge.pmd:pmd:5.1.2` to `qulice-maven-plugin` dependencies fixes it for me. I think it would be good to have the verson of PMD upgraded from 5.1.1 to 5.1.2 in `qulice-pmd`.

By the way, using newer PMD also fixes the errors described in #418

title: Can we remove the dependency on antlr-annotations?
body:
It is not used anymore by antlr4: the last antlr-runtime version 4.5 removed it:

https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/releases/tag/4.5

> Be aware that we no longer deploy a maven antlr4-annotations artifact and in fact we no longer use Java annotations in the Java runtime and so that code is disappeared.

Other reasons to remove it:
- `antlr4-annotations` doesn't support JDK>1.6.
- If `antlr-annotations` is present in the parent pom of a project that uses antlr4-runtime>4.3, then qulice will fail the build due to duplicated classes.

title: @version $Id$ not replaced
body:
There is qulice rule to put `$Id$` as version-text for version tag. That version text is not replaced during deployment. This can be verified by looking into sources.jar or javadoc.jar of, say, [jcabi-email](http://search.maven.org/#search|ga|1|a%3A%22jcabi-email%22).
Please, explain what is the point of putting `@version $Id$`?

title: Strange indentation requirements for the closing parenthesis in multiline method arguments
body:
Qulice makes me format a code fragment with indentation of four spaces less than I would expect:

https://github.com/Suseika/takes/blob/0dc21ea37284829c142c3d0b5eacd5af5b0a234f/src/test/java/org/takes/facets/auth/PsBasicDefaultTest.java#L77

``` java
MatcherAssert.assertThat(
    new PsBasic.Default(
        new String[]{
            "yvonne hey%20you urn:foo:z",
        }
    )
        .enter(
            "yvonne",
            "hey you"
    ) // ← This line
        .has(),
    Matchers.is(true)
);
```

I expected indentation to be like this, with one more level of indentation (+4 spaces):

``` java
        .enter(
            "yvonne",
            "hey you"
        ) // ← This line
```

Here is an example of an error I would get if I tried to indent that line how I wanted:

```
[ERROR] /src/test/java/org/takes/facets/auth/PsBasicDefaultTest.java[137]: method call rparen at indentation level 16 not at correct indentation, 12 (IndentationCheck)
```

Is there any reason for that, or is it a bug? Or maybe I shouldn't have put `.enter(` on a separate line  in the first place?

``` java
 * SERVICES; LOSS OF USE, DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION)
 * HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT,
 * STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE)
 * ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED
 * OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.
 */

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Locale;
import java.util.Map;

/**
 * Translates word yes to different languages.
 * @author Georgy Vlasov (wlasowegor@gmail.com)
 * @version $Id$
 * @since 0.12
 */
public final class Yes {
    /**
     * Map from 2-letter language codes to translations of word yes into that
     * language.
     */
    private final transient Map<String, String> translations;

    /**
     * Public ctor.
     */
    public Yes() {
        this.translations = new HashMap<String, String>();
        this.translations.put("ua", "так");
        this.translations.put("jp", "はい");
    }
}
```

pom.xml

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
    <groupId>org.group</groupId>
    <artifactId>artifact</artifactId>
    <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <parent>
        <groupId>com.jcabi</groupId>
        <artifactId>jcabi</artifactId>
        <version>1.17</version>
    </parent>
</project>
```

.rultor.yml:

``` yml
deploy:
  script: |-
    mvn clean deploy -Pqulice
```

LICENSE.txt:

```
Copyright (c) 2014-2015, jcabi.com
All rights reserved.

Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or without
modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions
are met: 1) Redistributions of source code must retain the above
copyright notice, this list of conditions and the following
disclaimer. 2) Redistributions in binary form must reproduce the above
copyright notice, this list of conditions and the following
disclaimer in the documentation and/or other materials provided
with the distribution. 3) Neither the name of the jcabi.com nor
the names of its contributors may be used to endorse or promote
products derived from this software without specific prior written
permission.

THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS
"AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT
NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND
FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL
THE COPYRIGHT HOLDER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT,
INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES
(INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR
SERVICES; LOSS OF USE, DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION)
HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT,
STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE)
ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED
OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.
```

The problem is that if rultor does e.g. deployment on these files with `-Pqulice` profile, then among other errors you can see the line:

```
/src/main/java/Yes.java[53]: The String "??????" appears 2 times in the file. (MultipleStringLiteralsCheck)
```

But there is no string in this file that appears 2 times.

[Yegor identified this](https://github.com/jcabi/jcabi-ssl-maven-plugin/pull/36#issuecomment-118214138) as a possible bug in qulice.

For convenience I threw together a [repo](https://github.com/Suseika/bugtest) where you can find all these files.
